The nitrogen footprint of different scales of restaurant food waste: a Beijing case study

Abstractï¼šRecentlyï¼Œresearchonfood lossand wasteandtherelatedenvironmental impact has increased globally.Wasted food createsnitrogenemissions throughoutthefoodsupplychainï¼Œfrom agricultural productionand foodprocessing to consumptionand waste disposal.Althoughthegenerationoffood waste mustbereduced,thelackof quantitative information onthe productionof householdand catering food waste hasled toanunderestimationof waste volumesand inhibited the development of suficient policy interventions designed todecrease food waste.Thepresent studyinvestigatedthevolumeof catering food wastegeneratedin Beijingandcalculated itsnitrogen fooprint.Inthepresentstudyï¼Œwe focusedonavoidable food waste,i.e.,allwastedfoodandrawmaterials thatcouldhave beenconsumed had theybeen prepared diffrently.Other bio-wastesï¼Œsuch as vegetable peelsï¼Œbean dregsï¼Œor bonesï¼Œwere not measured. During first-hand surveys of the catering sectorof urban Beijing in 2Ol3ï¼Œ136restaurants were studied.These establishmentswere divided into largeï¼Œmedium, smallï¼Œcanteenï¼Œandfast-foodrestaurant categories.Atotalof2,704samples werecolectedï¼Œeachconsisting of twoparts:

consumerquestionnaireand the weightof the sampleoffood waste generated byconsumersof the establishment.Thenï¼Œthe nitrogen footprintandits discharge totheenvironment werecalculated.The mainconclusionsof the present studyareï¼š(i) an estimated $7 4 . 3 9 \mathrm { ~ g ~ }$ of food waste is produced per non-household meal in urban Beijing.Food waste generation diered significantly among restaurant types. For exampleï¼Œ large restaurants generated the most wasteä¸€ $9 9 . 3 4 \textrm { g }$ ï¼Œthree times that produced by fast food restaurants $ { ( 3 0 . 2 7 ~ \mathrm { g } ) }$ .ï¼ˆiiï¼‰The food waste comprised many different food typesï¼Œthe most prominent ï¼ˆby weightï¼‰being vegetables $( 4 4 . 1 8 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œfollowed by aquatic products $( 1 2 . 0 4 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œpork( $( 8 . 6 0 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œbeans and bean products $( 7 . 6 9 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œpoultry $( 7 . 5 0 \%$ ï¼‰,wheat flour $( 6 . 9 6 \% )$ ï¼‰ï¼Œrice $( 5 . 3 6 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œbeef( $. 1 . 9 0 \%$ ï¼‰,mutton $( 1 . 8 9 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œother meat ( $1 . 2 2 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œeggs $( 1 . 2 0 \% )$ ï¼Œnuts $( 0 . 9 7 \% )$ ï¼‰ï¼Œother grains( $( 0 . 2 4 \% )$ ï¼Œfruits $( 0 . 2 0 \% )$ ï¼Œand dairy productsï¼ˆless than $0 . 1 \%$ ).ï¼ˆiiï¼‰Thetotal Ndischarge totheenvironment was16.37per non-household meal,and the nitrogen footprintof the catering food waste produced per non-household meal in Beijing was $0 . 2 2 \mathrm { ~ g ~ N / g ~ }$ .By food categoryï¼Œthe largest proportion of the calculated nitrogen emissions was generated by meat ( $( 3 0 . 6 5 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œbeans and bean products( $( 2 6 . 6 1 \% )$ ï¼‰ï¼Œand grains ï¼ˆ $1 2 . 9 0 \%$ ).By processï¼Œthe food production stages producing the largest proportions of the emissions were agricultural productionï¼ˆalmost $8 5 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œwaste management $( 7 . 6 0 \%$ ï¼‰ï¼Œand fertilizer production( $( 3 7 . 3 9 \%$ ).Nitrogen discharge to the atmosphereï¼Œsoilï¼Œand water was 7.34ï¼Œ1.34ï¼Œand $\ 7 . 6 9 \ \mathrm { \ g }$ per non-household mealï¼Œrespectively.ï¼ˆivï¼‰For the waste volumesï¼Œ large restaurants generated the most N dischargeä¸€ $2 2 . 5 3 \mathrm { \textrm { g } }$ three times that produced by fast food restaurants $\left( 5 . 6 7 \ \mathrm { g } \right)$ ï¼‰ï¼Œfollowedby the mediumï¼ˆ $1 8 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { g } { \cdot }$ ï¼‰andsmall ( $1 3 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { g }$ ï¼‰restaurants.
